text.p: Here is how major stock markets outside the United States ended on Monday.

LONDON - Britain's FTSE 100 index suffered its second consecutive sharp decline as the latest Wall Street jitters sparked a round of profit-taking in leading British shares. The FTSE 100 closed at 4,805.7, down 71.5 points, or 1.47 percent.

FRANKFURT - A merger of two of Germany's largest regional commercial banks failed to keep the 30-share DAX index from tumbling about two percent in bourse trade as a long-awaited wave of profit-taking hit the market. The DAX-30 index closed at 4,108.40, down 88.13 points, or 2.10 percent. In later screen-based trade the IBIS DAX index ended at 4,139.96, up 8.02 points, or 0.19 percent.

PARIS - Shares finished slightly lower after the government announced widely anticipated increases in corporate taxes to enable France to reduce its budget deficit and qualify for European monetary union. The CAC-40 index closed at 2,874.12, down 2.57 points, or 0.09 percent.

ZURICH - Shares continued their recent slide in nervous trading to end two percent lower after index heavyweights were pressured by derivatives-linked transactions. The Swiss market index closed at 5,620.5, down 116.6 points, or 2.03 percent.

MILAN - Shares closed mostly higher, as values swung back and forth after Wall Street's choppy start, with Fiat riding out the impact of a bonus share issue while Mediaset powered ahead. The All Share Mibtel index closed at 14,626, up 85 points, or 0.58 percent.

AMSTERDAM - Shares finished a see-saw session lower as nerves about U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony to Congress on Tuesday gained the upper hand in late trade. The AEX index closed at 931.34, down 10.45 points, or 1.11 percent.
TOKYO - The financial markets were closed today for a national holiday, they will reopen tomorrow. On Friday, the Nikkei 225 shed 269.93 points or 1.32 percent to finish at 20,249.32.

HONG KONG - Stocks lost momentum in late afternoon trade to close marginally down, chiefly due to weakness in properties and conglomerates as well as banking giant HSBC Holdings, brokers said. The Hang Seng index closed at 15,536.30, down 34.10 points, or 0.22 percent.

SYDNEY - The stock market ended 1.15 percent lower and near the day's lows in response to Wall Street's 1.6 percent dip on Friday. The All Ordinaries index closed at 2,653.4, down 30.8 points, or 1.15 percent.

JOHANNESBURG - Gold shares finished firmer but off highs reached in the morning as the volatile bullion price dipped a couple of dollars during the day. The All-share index closed at 7,431.9, up 7.0 points, or 0.09 percent. The All Gold index closed at 1,008.3, up 16.3 points, or 0.47 percent, while the Industrial index closed at 8,979.7, up 42.0 points, or 1.64 percent.
